questions.text: A child, upon disturbing a beehive, had several stings. After a few minutes, he developed shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse. What is the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of anaphylaxis following a bee sting. This is an example of IgE-mediated reaction or type 1 hypersensitivity.

Injurious immune reactions are called hypersensitivity reactions. There are four types of hypersensitivity reactions.

Immediate (Type 1) hypersensitivity is also called allergic reactions. They are induced by environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals.

IgE coats mast cells by binding to Fcεg receptors. Reexposure to the allergen leads to cross-linking of the IgE and FcεRI, activation of mast cells, and release of mediators. The principal mediators are histamine, proteases, and other granule contents like prostaglandins and leukotrienes and cytokines.

It occurs in two phases: immediate phase and late phase. The mediators are responsible for the immediate vascular and smooth muscle reactions and the late-phase reaction (inflammation). The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mildly annoying rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis.

The image given below shows the sequence of events in immediate hypersensitivity.

Related Pearl: Disorders Caused by Immediate Hypersensitivity

Clinical Syndrome

Clinical and Pathologic Manifestations

Anaphylaxis (may be caused by drugs, bee sting, food)

Fall in blood pressure (shock) caused by vascular dilation; airway obstruction due to laryngeal edema

Bronchial asthma

Airway obstruction caused by bronchial smooth muscle hyperactivity; inflammation and tissue injury caused by late-phase reaction

Allergic rhinitis, sinusitis (hay fever)

Increased mucus secretion; inflammation of upper airways, sinuses

Food allergies

Increased peristalsis due to contraction of intestinal muscles

questions.text: Arthus reaction is caused by which of the following process?
questions.solution:
Arthus reaction is characterized by a localized area of tissue necrosis due to immune-complex-mediated (type III hypersensitivity reaction) vasculitis in the skin.

This reaction can be produced experimentally by intracutaneous injection of antigen in a previously immunised animal that contains circulating antibodies against the antigen. As the antigen diffuses into the vessel wall, it binds with the preformed antibody, and immune complexes are formed locally. These complexes precipitate in the vessel walls and cause fibrinoid necrosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female patient presents with ptosis, diplopia, and progressive muscular weakness towards the end of the day. She has improvements in symptoms after administering edrophonium. The given clinical condition is an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given clinical condition is highly suggestive of myasthenia gravis. It is an example of a type II hypersensitivity reaction.

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease that is usually associated with autoantibodies directed against acetylcholine receptors. In Type II hypersensitivity, antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause. These antibodies destroy cells, trigger inflammation, or interfering with normal functions.

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: A 6-year-old child abruptly develops malaise, fever, nausea, oliguria, and smoky, cola-colored urine 2 weeks after recovery from a sore throat. He is found to have periorbital edema and mild hypertension. Urine examination shows dysmorphic red cells and red cell casts in the urine with mild proteinuria. Which type of hypersensitivity is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephritic syndrome due to post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. This is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction.

In type III hypersensitivity, immune complexes may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement. The pathogenesis of systemic immune complex disease can be divided into three phases:

  • Formation of immune complexes
  • Deposition of immune complexes
  • Inflammation and tissue injury

This results in various manifestations like vasculitis, glomerulonephritis and arthritis.

Examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions:

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Reactive arthritis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction
  • Farmer’s lung
  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
  • Type II lepra reaction
  • Henoch–Schonlein purpura

The image given below shows the mechanism of type III hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a fever and chronic cough is administered 0.1 mL of purified protein derivative intradermally over the forearm. After a few hours, the injection site appears as follows.  Which of the following does this represent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario shows a positive tuberculin test. It is a classical example of type IV or delayed or cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction.

Tuberculin test involves intradermal injection of purified protein derivative (PPD, also called tuberculin), a protein-containing antigen of the tubercle bacillus. In a previously sensitized individual, reddening and induration of the site appear in 8 to 12 hours, reach a peak in 24 to 72 hours, and thereafter slowly subside. 

Morphologically, delayed-type hypersensitivity is characterized by the accumulation of mononuclear cells, mainly CD4+ T cells and macrophages, around venules. The cell-mediated type of hypersensitivity is caused by inflammation resulting from cytokines produced by CD4+ T cells and cell killing by CD8+ T cells.

Related Pearl: Examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity

Type IV Hypersensitivity Reactions 

  • Tuberculin reaction
  • Lepromin test
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Chronic graft rejection
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Type I lepra reaction
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Psoriasis

questions.text: True about anaphylactoid reaction are all except:
questions.solution:
Anaphylactoid reactions are those reactions that are similar to the anaphylactic reactions but are not IgE mediated. These reactions are caused by direct degranulation of the mast cells or basophils, which causes the release of mediators.

Unlike the classic anaphylaxis which occurs on re-exposure to the allergen, the anaphylactoid reaction can occur even on the first exposure. The most common agents that can cause an anaphylactoid reaction include NSAIDs and radiocontrast media.

In 2014, World Allergy Organisation has introduced two new terms:

  • Immunologic anaphylaxis - It includes anaphylactic reactions mediated by IgE, IgG (in animals), and immune complex/ complement-mediated reactions.
  • Non-immunologic anaphylaxis (previously called anaphylactoid reaction) - It includes reactions caused by agents which cause massive degranulation of mast cells or basophils in the absence of immunoglobulin.

questions.text: Which of the following autoimmune diseases are not mediated by antibodies?
questions.solution:
Rheumatoid arthritis is mediated by T cells, not antibodies.

Antibody-mediated diseases:

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Vasculitis caused by ANCA
  • Goodpasture syndrome
  • Myasthenia gravis
  • Acute rheumatic fever
  • Graves disease
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Insulin resistant diabetes

T cell-mediated diseases:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Psoriasis
  • Type 1 diabetes mellitus
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Contact sensitivity

Note: In T cell mediated diseases, although the role of T cells have been demonstrated, antibodies may also be involved in tissue injury.

questions.text: Which gene is most frequently implicated in autoimmunity?
questions.solution:
PTPN22 gene is most frequently implicated in autoimmunity.

PTPN22, which encodes the protein tyrosine phosphatase, is associated with the following conditions:

  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)
  • Type 1 diabetes

Because these disorders have a fairly high prevalence, PTPN22 is said to be the gene that is most frequently implicated in autoimmunity.

Option A: Mutations in FOXP3 cause a systemic autoimmune disease called IPEX (immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, X-linked).

Option C: Polymorphisms in the gene encoding for NOD2 are associated with Crohn's disease.

Option D: AIRE mutation is associated with the autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (APS-1).

questions.text: During development, thymic cells recognizing self-antigens are removed to prevent autoimmunity. Which gene among the following is involved in the process?
questions.solution:
The above process is called central tolerance and the AIRE (AutoImmune REgulator) protein is necessary for this process.

Immature self-reactive T and B lymphocyte clones recognize self-antigens during their maturation in the central lymphoid organs (thymus for T cells, bone marrow for B cells). They are killed or rendered harmless.

The removal of self reacting T lymphocytes in the thymus is called negative selection/ deletion. For this process, AIRE protein is needed. Mutations in the AIRE gene results in autoimmune disorders (autoimmune polyendocrinopathy).

B cells undergo a process called receptor editing. When developing B cells encounter an antigen, it formulates a change in the receptor that makes the antigen unrecognizable. Self-reacting B cells can also undergo apoptosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for autoimmunity in Epstein-Barr virus infection?
questions.solution:
Autoimmunity in Epstein–Barr virus (EBV) infection is the result of polyclonal B cell activation.

Microbes may induce other abnormalities that promote autoimmune reactions. Some viruses, such as EBV and HIV, cause polyclonal B-cell activation, which may result in the production of autoantibodies.

The role of infections in autoimmunity is exemplified by the following:

  1. Molecular mimicry of antigenic cross-reactivity: The structural similarity of the microbial antigens and self-antigens. Rheumatic heart disease is an example in which streptococcal proteins cross-react with myocardial proteins causing myocarditis.
  2. Upregulation of co-stimulatory molecules by infectious organisms.
  3. Polyclonal B cell activation: Caused by EBV and HIV, resulting in the production of autoantibodies.
  4. Alteration of tissue antigens: Infections may alter tissue self-antigens so that they activate T cells and lose the property of self-tolerance.

questions.text: Homogeneous or diffuse nuclear staining pattern may reflect antibodies to all the following except:
questions.solution:
Homogeneous or diffuse nuclear staining does not reflect antibodies to RNA. The nucleolar pattern of staining represents antibodies to RNA.

 Antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) are directed against antibodies to:

  • DNA
  • Histones
  • Nonhistone proteins bound to RNA
  • Nucleolar antigens

The most widely used method for detecting ANAs is indirect immunofluorescence. The pattern of nuclear fluorescence suggests the type of antibody present in the patient’s serum.

Related Pearl: Pattern of nuclear body suggests the type of antibody present in patient’s serum.

Five basic patterns of nuclear fluorescence is recognized for anti-nuclear antibodies:

Staining pattern Antigen
Homogenous or diffuse nuclear staining Antibodies to chromatin, histones, and occasionally double-stranded DNA
Rim or peripheral staining Antibodies to double-stranded DNA, and sometimes to nuclear envelope proteins
Speckled pattern

One of the most commonly observed patterns of fluorescence, the least specific. 

Antibodies to non-DNA nuclear constituents such as Sm antigen, ribonucleoprotein, and SS-A and SS-B reactive antigens.
Nucleolar pattern

Few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represent antibodies to RNA.

Seen in systemic sclerosis.
Centromeric pattern

Seen in systemic sclerosis

Often contain antibodies specific for centromeres, which give rise to this pattern.

questions.text: What type of cell is the lupus erythematosus cell?
questions.solution:
The lupus erythematosus (LE) cell is a phagocytic neutrophil or macrophage.

Nuclei of damaged cells react with ANAs, lose their chromatin pattern, and become homogeneous to produce LE bodies or hematoxylin bodies. Phagocytic neutrophils or macrophages engulf the denatured nucleus of an injured cell. Demonstration of LE cells in vitro was used in the past for the diagnosis of SLE.

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady presents with the following finding. On further investigations, anti-ds DNA and anti-Smith antibodies are found to be positive. Which of the following is not seen in the given clinical condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is highly suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). In this condition, lymphocytic infiltration in the salivary gland is not seen. However, this finding is seen in Sjogren's syndrome. 

If cell nuclei are exposed to anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs), they can bind to them. The nuclei of damaged cells react with ANAs, lose their chromatin pattern, and become homogeneous. They are called lupus erythematosus (LE) bodies or hematoxylin bodies.

An acute necrotizing vasculitis involving capillaries, small arteries, and arterioles with fibrinoid necrosis is seen in SLE. Central penicilliary arteries in the spleen may show concentric intimal and smooth muscle cell hyperplasia, producing so-called onion-skin lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the IgG4 spectrum?
questions.solution:
Celiac disease is not an IgG4-Related disease.

IgG4-related disease (IgG4-RD) is a newly recognized constellation of disorders characterized by tissue infiltrates dominated by IgG4 antibody-producing plasma cells and lymphocytes, particularly T cells, storiform fibrosis, obliterative phlebitis, and usually increased serum IgG4.

IgG4-RD spectrum includes:

  • Mikulicz syndrome - enlargement and fibrosis of salivary and lacrimal glands
  • Riedel thyroiditis
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis
  • Autoimmune pancreatitis
  • Inflammatory pseudotumors of the orbit, lungs, and kidney
